The cloud continues to be good business for Salesforce.com.The maker of business software late Tuesday reported better-than-expected Q1 results, as more companies adopt software delivered via the cloud.The company's revenue outlook for Q2 also beat Wall Street views, and it raised its EPS and revenue forecast for the year.Salesforce.com (CRM) stock was up nearly 1% in after-hours trading after the company released its results. Its stock fell a fraction in Tuesday's regular session. Shares are down 4% for the year.Salesforce.com has become the No. 1 provider of customer relationship management software.Delivering CRM through the cloud enables the company to beat rivals SAP (SAP) and Oracle (ORCL), says Steve Koenig, an analyst for Wedbush Securities. Oracle acquired Siebel Systems, a maker of CRM software, for $5.85 billion in 2005.Salesforce.com "created a product that was much simpler and easier to use than Siebel," he said.The company is still outpacing SAP and Oracle in the CRM market, agrees Steven Ashley, an analyst for Robert W. Baird & Co."SAP doesn't really have clouds that compete with Salesforce.com's clouds," he said. "Oracle does, (but) we have not heard of them being very competitive with their cloud offering."Salesforce.com's growth has accelerated after adding marketing services. It acquired ExactTarget, a marketing services company, for $2.5 billion last year."All of those Salesforce.com reps are out in the field pushing ExactTarget and cross-selling those products into the huge Salesforce.com installed base," Karl Keirstead, an analyst for Deutsche Bank, told IBD. "So it's natural to expect some growth acceleration and Salesforce.com has done a good job with that."For the quarter ended April 30, Salesforce reported earnings per share minus items of 11 cents, up a penny from the year-earlier period and a penny above the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Revenue rose 37% to $1.23 billion, edging views of $1.2 billion. That growth rate is on par with Q4 but better than the earlier six quarters.For the current quarter, the company expects EPS ex items of 11 or 12 cents, up from 9 cents. Analysts had modeled 12 cents.The company expects revenue of $1.285 billion to $1.29 billion, up 34% to 35%, where analysts had been expecting $1.27 billion.Salesforce raised its revenue outlook for the year to $5.3 billion-$5.34 billion, up 30% to 31%, from its previous estimate of $5.25 billion-$5.3 billion. Analysts have estimated $5.29 billion.The company expects EPS ex items of 49 cents to 51 cents, up a penny from its previous forecast, and up from 35 cents last year. Analysts expect 50 cents.In Q1, revenue from professional services and related areas increased 58% to $79.4 million.Deferred revenue rose 34%, to $2.32 billion.Ashley says Salesforce will continue to see faster growth from its services software, which provides customer service data on multiple devices, and its Force.com platform, which lets companies develop software applications for business-related social networking purposes.Salesforce.com's research and development costs jumped 43% to $188.3 million. Sales and marketing costs rose 37% to $639.3 million. "Salesforce.com is still hiring new sales reps and investing in them," Keirstead said.

Francisco D'Souza is used to surfing the big waves of change.He was born in Nairobi, Kenya; grew up in 10 other countries, including Panama and Congo; and had to learn languages just to survive in school.During the boom of the late 1990s, he helped launch the tech service firm Cognizant (CTSH), was its North American director through the tech crash of the early 2000s and became CEO in January 2007.Despite the recession that started late that year, D'Souza has overseen revenue growth from $1.4 billion to 2012's $7.4 billion while providing everything from software system integration to high-tech strategic consulting.Arvind Ramnani of BNP Paribas predicts that Cognizant's revenue will bulge to $8.9 billion in 2013 and $10.3 billion in 2014.Meanwhile, Cognizant's stock has rocketed 525% since late 2008."I think the key to success in the business world today is to learn how to adapt rapidly," D'Souza, 45, told IBD.D'Souza is the son of an Indian diplomat, which meant the family moved to a different country every few years. His parents put their children in native schools instead of the international ones, favored by many foreigners, that minimized contact with the locals.Worldly"We learned to thrive in a flat world long before the term became in vogue," said D'Souza. "My multicultural experience had a decisive impact on the way we consciously built Cognizant to serve a global marketplace."His father bought him a computer when he was 13.Frank taught himself programming and in three years developed software to manage the inventory of a division of the Trinidad army.At 18 he worked as a teller in an international bank in Hong Kong during the day and went to the University of East Asia in Macau at night. The bank was using a punch-card system that was no longer supported by the vendor, so he helped implement a software program.A year later he worked with a small startup to invent a mass fax machine that could send out advertising for products and daily stock quotes, in the process learning the basics of entrepreneurship.After earning a bachelor's degree in business in 1991, D'Souza entered the MBA program at Pittsburgh's Carnegie Mellon University. He had to take a job on campus to pay the bills, so he pulled all-nighters before tests and took power naps between classes.He dreamed of starting a tech company, but had no green card to let him stay in America as an entrepreneur. After graduation in 1992, he joined credit information provider Dun & Bradstreet (DNB) and went to Germany. The next year, he heard D&B wanted to focus on emerging markets, so he volunteered to help create a software service arm in Chennai, India.Originally called DBSS and servicing D&B's in-house needs, the unit was spun off as Cognizant in 1996 and the next year moved to Teaneck, N.J. It went public in 1998.Meanwhile, D'Souza got his green card, and from 1997 to 2003 he directed North American operations and business development, getting through the dot-com bust by doing information technology projects that bigger firms ignored."One day, I might be out selling to prospective clients; the next, I could be figuring out how to process our payroll," he said.D'Souza's lesson is that marketing experience can be a great plus to help reach your career goals, no matter what they are. He served as chief operating officer from December 2003 to December 2006 before becoming CEO at 38.Cognizant rolled onto Fortune's "100 Fastest-Growing Companies" list from 2003 to 2012 and became one of the Fortune 500 in 2011.While it has big-name allies such as Microsoft (MSFT), Oracle (ORCL) and SAS, Cognizant faces competition from giants such as IBM (IBM), Accenture (ACN) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ).Cognizant does general business and management consulting, which can range from business process re-engineering to mergers-and-acquisitions program management. Its sweet spot is to address points where technology and operations intersect, such as integrating complex systems and implementing new applications.Cognizant operates in over 40 countries, but D'Souza cautions that keeping costs low for clients should not be the sole value when it comes to outsourcing."Clients today need to address a dual mandate — driving costs down in their core business, while simultaneously innovating and transforming their business by leveraging the new SMAC stack," D'Souza said, referring to social mobility, data analytics and cloud service. "With structural shifts in economy, business and technology, enterprises are forced to re-examine how they operate, moving from merely incremental levels of performance efficiency to building new digital business capabilities. In this context, not only do they need to run better; they need to run different."GrowthCognizant has convinced so many C-level executives that it can do a superior job at reasonable prices while driving their innovation agenda that its client list has grown from 400 to 1,100 under D'Souza.His firm currently has more than 166,000 employees globally."It has also doubled revenue per client over the past five years," wrote Ramnani. "The trend is reflective of the value that Cognizant provides to its clients in an environment where they were consolidating their vendor relationships."Cognizant's inroads into some industries are nothing short of stunning. Its customers include 27 of the top 30 global pharmaceutical companies, nine of the 10 leading biotechs, 12 of the biggest medical device makers, four of five online powerhouses, as well as six of the top 10 North American financial institutions and all top 10 in Europe.Part of the company's formula for gaining loyalty is deep experience with its Two-in-a-Box approach. One part of the team is a Cognizant business expert who has over 15 years' experience in that industry and works at the client's site. That specialist works with an IT specialist who has the same level of experience implementing projects.When the recession hit in late 2007, D'Souza decided to invest in growth. Meanwhile, rivals were cutting back.D'Souza told everyone at Cognizant to spend more time with customers and more effort in marketing to potential ones. Over the next few years, he traveled to meet many of them, showing that the company was committed top to bottom to making itself invaluable.Differentiating itself from tech outsourcing companies, Cognizant acquired consultancies and emphasized its long-term strategic advisory relationships.All For OneIn February 2012, D'Souza made a radical decision. The company was reorganized under three leaders to leave him free from day-to-day operational management to concentrate on future technology.With $3.36 billion in cash and short-term investments and no debt, Cognizant is placing its bet on balancing its core revenue sources with a gamble on potential ones.Headed by President Gordon Coburn and group CEOs Rajeev Mehta and Chandrasekaran Ramakrishnan, Cognizant's services are divided into three horizons:• 1. The cash cow of application development, maintenance and testing, enterprise resource planning, data warehousing and business intelligence.• 2. Fast-growing management consulting, IT infrastructure management and business process.• 3. New technologies and markets such as Latin America."D'Souza is risking both his own reputation and career," wrote Forbes India. "But as Albert Einstein once said: Problems cannot be solved by the same level of thinking that created them."D'Souza's lesson is that when things are going well, look for ways to break out to the next level."I've seen CEOs who are strong in leadership or management, but Frank is truly rare in having such outsized capabilities in both," said Malcolm Frank, executive vice president and chief strategist at Cognizant. "I've seen him build a galvanized sense of purpose across the entire company with a compelling long-term vision, then give us whiplash by immediately switching to work closely with a particular business unit, holding them to key metrics and deliverables in incredible detail."

Teradata (TDC) stock plunged 16.5% in morning trading the stock market Tuesday, a day after the Big Data analytics company lowered its guidance for 2013 and Q3, citing drooping demand in Asia, the Middle East and Africa.

The company said Q3 revenue from Asia-Pacific fell 21%, while sales in the Middle East and Africa fell 19%, both short of expectations. Teradata blamed the shortfall on unfavorable exchange rates. Excluding the U.S., sales in the Americas also were below expectations.
Teradata is now forecasting adjusted income of $2.70 to $2.80 per share for 2013, "flat or "approximately the same" as its 2012 revenue of $2.67 billion.
The company had earlier estimated EPS minus items of $3.05 to $3.20 and revenue of $2.82 billion to $2.93 billion, up 6% to 10%.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 2013 revenue of $2.695 billion on EPS of $2.83 per share.
For Q3, the company now estimates EPS ex items of 69 cents to 70 cents on revenue of about $665 million. Analysts had been expecting 73 cents and $672.85 million.
At least four investment banks downgraded their rating on Teradata stock, but several maintained high ratings.
William Blair, however, maintained its outperform. But the investment house lowered its forecast for 2013 revenue to $2.67 billion from $2.78 billion and EPS ex items to $2.70 from $2.86.

"As a result of the strong performance within the U.S. and Europe, we continue to believe that (Teradata) has not lost traction in the competitive environment," wrote analyst Bhavan Suri in a research note Tuesday.

Pacific Crest Securities also maintained its outperform rating and price target of 60 on Teradata stock, saying in a research note Tuesday that it sees potential cyclical uplift for the company in Q4 and the first half of 2014, if its "pipeline" is still healthy.
RBC Capital Markets kept its outperform rating but it cut its estimates and lowered its price target to 55 from 70.
Teradata stock was trading near 43.90 Tuesday morning, at a 10-month low.
Teradata is slated to report its Q3 results before the market open on Oct. 31.

The company's rivals include much larger Oracle (ORCL) and IBM (IBM), which is set to report its Q3 results after the close Wednesday. Handling A Choppy Uptrend: Fifth In A SeriesDon't sneer at a base-on-base formation. You may think you're looking at an indecisive stock.But base-on-base patterns also appear for stocks whose biggest problem is a rough market.A stock forms a base. It doesn't even have to be a good base. As the stock rises, there's no guarantee the market will cooperate.And, after all, the broad market is the M in CAN SLIM. Without it, you're swimming upstream.So let's say the breakout faces a market that suddenly shifts into a correction. Or the market retains its uptrend, but in a rough and volatile fashion — like we've seen recently. That fresh breakout can easily stall in such situations.What then? The stock's run could be dead. But many of these stalled leaders go on to form a second base. Here's how you know it's a base-on-base:• Both bases are valid, although the first base can be flawed.• The high point of the second base is no more than 20% above the buy point from the first base.• The low point of the second base may dip slightly below the high point of the first base.Oracle (ORCL) showed a fine example in 1999 of how a breakout can run into a bad market, and how a stock can rectify an ugly base.Oracle built its first base of the eventual base-on-base from February through September 1. This cup-with-handle ran 49% deep and showed plenty of loose, sloppy trade.This was an ugly base, and you couldn't be blamed for letting it pass.Oracle broke out Sept. 3 2 and floated to a new trading range 3 as the broad market moved into a sideways mode. The low of this range, 39.88, undercut the prior base's high by 3%. Lovely.Seven weeks of consolidation tracked nicely with the Nasdaq. Then the market took off like an escaped convict, and Oracle was one of the leaders in what would become an historic run.The stock triggered the new buy point from its second phase of the base-on-base on Oct. 29 and Nov. 1, running past 47.04.So what did Oracle accomplish? By building a base-on-base, Oracle bided its time until the broad market provided the needed updraft. And that same base-on-base turned an ugly pattern into a tighter, neater base that you'd feel comfortable buying into.

EMC and its spinoff, VMware, along with their progeny called Pivotal, make a formidable trio as IT firms aim to survive and thrive in the cloud computing era. The Internet cloud proffers a new kind of competition. Manhattan Associates (MANH) can still grow even when it doesn't hit on all cylinders — and investors are OK with that, so far.

The maker of software to manage warehouse and e-commerce operations, which competes with business software kingpins SAP (SAP) and Oracle (ORCL), last month reported Q3 results that soundly beat analyst views even though its license revenue fell by nearly double digits.

Moreover, Manhattan executives told analysts on a conference call no fewer than seven times that its near-term growth could be affected by the uncertain macro-economy. And they underscored the point by cutting the company's annual revenue forecast for the year by $3 million.
In most cases, a single mention of market uncertainty and lowered guidance would be enough to send a company's shares plummeting.
Not so for Manhattan Associates, which, to be sure, also hiked its earnings outlook for the year.

Manhattan stock jumped 15% after the earnings call to near 110. It's up another 7% since then and up nearly 100% for the year. On Dec. 20, the company announced a four-for-one stock split, effective with Tuesday's close, with stock trading on the split-adjusted basis set to start Jan. 13.
Unusual Reaction
Investor reaction has been unusual and perplexing, says Mark Schappel, analyst for the Benchmark Co.
"It seems the market doesn't care" about the words of caution, Schappel told IBD. He rates the stock a hold.
Manhattan, says Schappel, is a company that can win even when it's losing.
"The big issue is that the company has done a very good job driving earnings growth on flat product sales," he said.

Manhattan's supply chain management software has caught on with a growing number of companies, particularly retailers, that need to make sure their products are in the right place to keep up with customer demand, says Dwight Klappich, an analyst for market tracker Gartner.
"Manhattan is the Mercedes-Benz of the logistics applications marketplace; it really serves the needs of the most sophisticated complex users," Klappich told IBD.
The company's annual revenue outlook of $407 million to $415 million implies Q4 revenue of $101 million to $103 million, just shy of views of $103.4 million.
For Q3, Manhattan reported a 12% rise in revenue overall vs the year-earlier quarter to $107.8 million, but its software license revenue fell 9% to $14.7 million.
On the other hand, services revenue jumped 18.2% to $85 million. The rest of its revenue comes from related hardware, which rose 3% to $8 million.
The news from the quarter was both bad and good, Schappel says.
"The revenue growth is being driven by their services business, but services (revenue) doesn't ... have the margin capability that the product software revenue does," he said.
License growth has been an issue for Manhattan. Its year-over-year license revenue growth has fallen in four of its last seven quarters.

One reason is its focus on large companies, particularly big retailers. On its conference call, Manhattan CEO Eddie Capel said pursuing million-dollar-plus contracts can impact revenue projections if deals take longer than expected to implement or if a contract signing is delayed from one quarter to the next.

" ... we feel like we are seeing deals move out but not go away, and it's just becoming a bit more tricky quarter-over-quarter to forecast exactly when those particularly bigger deals are going to close," he said.
Some transitions take longer than others, says Gartner's Klappich.

"Big e-commerce retailers or retailers moving from just traditional brick-and-mortar to more e-commerce tend to be very complicated environments," he said. "Their license-to-services ratio is probably always going to be a little lower than some other vendors, largely because of the market they go after."
Customers Include Cost Plus
Manhattan's customers include Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) unit Cost Plus World Markets, Adidas Group, Lamps Plus and Columbia Sportswear (COLM).
Apart from its core warehouse management product, Manhattan also sells software systems to help companies manage their transportation systems. That accounts for roughly 30% of revenue.
One way Manhattan can grow is by selling its transportation product to its warehouse customers, Schappel says. But he says its longer-term growth prospects are less certain.

"Their biggest challenge is, where do they take their business? How do they grow their business, because the company is very anti-acquisition," he said. "They are content with being a supply chain execution company and sketching out that vision."
More offshore expansion is likely, Klappich says.

"They have been very strong in North America," he said. "They need to take that and go to other parts of the marketplace and focus on their strength, which is starting from complex retail and e-commerce, and build on that."Manhattan Associates (MANH) can still grow even when it doesn't hit on all cylinders — and investors are OK with that, so far.The maker of software to manage warehouse and e-commerce operations, which competes with business software kingpins SAP (SAP) and Oracle (ORCL), last month reported Q3 results that soundly beat analyst views even though its license revenue fell by nearly double digits.Moreover, Manhattan executives told analysts on a conference call no fewer than seven times that its near-term growth could be affected by the uncertain macro-economy. And they underscored the point by cutting the company's annual revenue forecast for the year by $3 million.In most cases, a single mention of market uncertainty and lowered guidance would be enough to send a company's shares plummeting.Not so for Manhattan Associates, which, to be sure, also hiked its earnings outlook for the year.Manhattan stock jumped 15% after the earnings call to near 110. It's up another 7% since then and up nearly 100% for the year. Stocks added to early gains near midday Friday with tech stocks leading a charge to new highs.

The Nasdaq forged ahead in the stock market today, up 0.9% to a new high. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 held their early highs, and were up 0.5% each. Volume remained heavy, boosted by options expiration trading, up 49% on the Nasdaq and 146% on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Thursday.

Software developers were all over the map in Friday's session. RedHat (RHT) continued to hold the high ground among S&P 500 stocks with a 19% gain. Tibco Software (TIBX) remained down 15% after reporting disappointing Q3 results late Thursday.
Marketing software developer Responsys (MKTG) vaulted 38% higher on news that Oracle (ORCL) planned to buy the San Bruno, Calif.-based company for around $1.5 billion. Oracle shares rose a fraction.
VMware (VMW) snapped up 4% in powerful trade. The enterprise software developer is just below its Oct. 22 high, and not quite 4% above an 87.51 buy point in a cup with handle base.
Makers of three-dimensional printers were posting strong gains. Stratasys (SSYS) climbed 3%, 3D Systems (DDD) more than 2% — both in heavy trade. 3D Systems' move pushed it to a new high.

E-commerce software maker Demandware (DWRE) can take share from IBM (IBM) and Oracle (ORCL) in the enterprise market, says Barclays, which on Thursday initiated coverage on the company with an overweight rating.

Demandware stock, which has doubled since June, was up 1.5% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 62. Demandware helps large companies create and manage online retail stores. Its customers include Brooks Brothers, Lands' End and L'Oreal.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Demandware Q4 profit to slide 11% to 15 cents per share, with revenue rising 26% to 33 million.
Barclays analyst Raimo Lenschow set a price target of 76 for Demandware stock.

"Large enterprise businesses generally account for a disproportionate amount of retail e-commerce spending, and Demandware's solution is able to effectively compete in this market currently dominated by IBM, Oracle and in-house solutions," he wrote.

"Winning a competitive displacement is challenging but from the examples of Salesforce (CRM) and Workday (WDAY) in (human resource management), enterprise customers are clearly willing to replace legacy on-premise functionality with a cloud equivalent," he added.

Canaccord Genuity analyst Richard Davis on Tuesday said Demandware stock might "triple in five years," as IBD reported.E-commerce software maker Demandware (DWRE) can take share from IBM (IBM) and Oracle (ORCL) in the enterprise market, says Barclays, which on Thursday initiated coverage on the company with an overweight rating.Demandware stock, which has doubled since June, was up 1.5% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 62. Wall Street rose for a second day Tuesday, leaving the major indexes just below record highs, as higher oil prices boosted energy stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, the Nasdaq climbed 0.4% and the S&P 500 ended up 0.3%, with the latter two finishing just 1% below their all-time peaks. Volume was about 10% higher on both the NYSE and Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.

In the stock market today, oil producer Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) and driller Diamond Offshore (DO) each rose 6%, leading the S&P 500. Oil prices jumped more than 3% to just below $48 a barrel amid a strike by oil workers in Brazil and a port shutdown in Libya.

Noah Holdings (NOAH) led the IBD 50, jumping 10% in heavy volume as it climbs the right side of a deep base. The provider of wealth management services in China is due to report Q3 results Nov. 16. Profit for the period is seen rising 21% to 41 cents a share, which would be the biggest gain in four quarters.
Medical products stock Cambrex (CBM) rose more than 6% after a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report. It's also climbing the right side of a new base.

In post-session trading, luxury electric vehicle maker Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose sharply on a narrower-than-expected Q3 loss. The stock fell more than 2% during the regular session, ending 27% off its 52-week high.
Shares of real estate website Zillow (Z) was down about 5% after hours following its Q3 results.

Also after the close, Groupon (GPN) edged higher after its Q3 report. The provider of discounts from retailers also announced that COO Rich Williams will replace Eric Lefkofsky as CEO. Lefkofsky will become chairman.
LGI Homes (LGIH), Facebook (FB), Epam Systems (EPAM) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) are among companies reporting quarterly earnings Wednesday.

Global spending on information technology is expected to rise 3.1% to $3.8 trillion in 2014, up from growth of just 0.4% last year, research firm Gartner said Monday.
The enterprise software group is expected to show the fastest growth, with sales rising 6.8% to $320 billion, a plus for industry leaders that include Oracle (ORCL) and Salesforce.com (CRM).

The increased spending on enterprise software is coming partly from the growth in Big Data, a term used to describe how companies are using software and related services to better comprehend massive inflows of digital information from numerous sources.

A report last month from research firm IDC said the market for Big Data technology and services is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 27% and reach $32.4 billion in 2017, about six times the growth rate for the information technology market overall, as IBD reported. It's a trend that benefits Big Data software companies such as Splunk (SPLK), Tableau Software (DATA) and Marketo (MKTO).

The increased investments in enterprise software is also coming from businesses aiming to improve customer service, with customer relationship management and supply chain management seen as areas of strong growth. Among the top-performing stocks in this sector is Manhattan Associates (MANH). Manhattan's supply chain management software has caught on with a growing number of companies, particularly retailers that need to make sure their products are in the right place to keep up with customer demand, as IBD recently reported.
For 2014, Gartner predicts the IT service sector will show the second-fastest growth, rising 4.5% to $963 billion, up from growth of 1.8% last year.

Spending on computer devices, which includes PCs, mobile phones and tablets, will grow 4.3% to $697 billion, a sharp reversal from a 2.1% decline in 2013. Much of that growth will come from mobile phones and tablets, where Apple (AAPL) is a market leader. IDC previously said it expects PC sales to fall 10% in 2013, and decline another 3.8% in 2014. It's a trend that has hurt Microsoft (MSFT) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), as consumers rely more on tablets and smartphones.
In the data center systems sector, where EMC (EMC) is the industry leader, Gartner projects spending growth of 2.6% to $143 billion, compared with a slight decline in 2013.
In telecom services, Gartner expects revenue growth of 1.2% to $1.65 trillion, where it previously had forecast 1.9% growth.
Related:

Investors are buying into the Workday (WDAY) story. Workday stock was up 12% in midday trading Tuesday, a day after the company reported fiscal Q3 results and gave a fiscal Q4 revenue outlook that soundly beat estimates, as IBD reported. Steven Ashley, an analyst for Robert Baird & Co., raised his rating on the company from neutral to outperform. He…
Workday late Monday posted fiscal Q3 earnings that soundly beat estimates, as did its Q4 sales outlook, as the software maker continues to challenge Oracle and SAP.
The company's revenue outlook for the current quarter was also ahead of Wall Street views.
Workday (WDAY) stock was up 8.5% in after-hours trading Monday, after its earnings release, and is up 34% this year through Monday's regular session.
The company makes human resources and financial software-as-a-service that users access via the Internet cloud, competing against longtime business software leaders Oracle (ORCL) and SAP (SAP).
Workday is becoming a leading provider in human capital management and finance management software, analysts say. It's also rolling out data analytics software.

Workday is leveraging the cloud, one of the fastest-growing areas of technology, to challenge Oracle and SAP, says Steve Koenig, an analyst for Wedbush Securities. The incumbents also are moving more to cloud offerings, but they've lagged, Koenig says.

"Workday is very small but they've got the entire Oracle and SAP base to feast on, and they are going to pick off a very significant piece of that base over time — there is no doubt about it," he said.
Workday was co-founded by David Duffield, who is co-CEO. Duffield also founded PeopleSoft, another maker of HR software, which Oracle acquired in a hostile takeover in 2004.

For the quarter ended Oct. 31, Workday reported a per-share loss, minus items, of 12 cents vs. a 39-cent loss in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected a per-share loss of 17 cents.
Revenue rose 76% to $127.9 million, where analysts had expected $117.6 million.
The company also announced that it had added Yahoo (YHOO) co-founder Jerry Yang to its board.
For the current quarter, Workday expects revenue of $133 million to $138 million, up 63% to 69%. Analysts had expected $128.9 million, or growth of 58%.
Workday doesn't provide an earnings outlook. Analysts expect a per-share loss ex items of 18 cents vs. a 19-cent loss in the year-ago period.
The company is growing its core HR business while attracting more users to its financial platform, Workday co-CEO Aneel Bhusri told analysts on a conference call.
"We are translating our success in HR and moving it to financials," Bhusri said.
Workday said it added 50 customers in Q3, including eight companies among the largest 2,000.

Workday has emerged as the leading player among software-as-a-service companies that sell their products through a monthly or annual subscription via the cloud, says Scott Berg, an analyst for Northland Capital Markets.
"It's the fastest-growing company in all of SaaS right now," he said.
But growth comes at a cost.
Workday's research and development costs rose 76% in Q3. Its sales and marketing expenses rose 66%.
Recruiting more salespeople and systems integrators is necessary for Workday to continue to challenge Oracle and SAP, Koenig says.
"They need to train and develop their sales force and third-party systems integrators," he said. "Their market footprint is a lot smaller than their competitors."
Integrating its products is one key. The company is working on tightly integrating its human capital management software with its financial management product.
That will be critical to attract larger customers, Berg says.
"Until Workday is able to sell that properly, I don't think some customers (can) switch all their HR over to Workday," he said.

"Until Workday is able to sell that properly, I don't think some customers (can) switch all their HR over to Workday," he said.Workday late Monday posted fiscal Q3 earnings that soundly beat estimates, as did its Q4 sales outlook, as the software maker continues to challenge Oracle and SAP.The company's revenue outlook for the current quarter was also ahead of Wall Street views.Workday (WDAY) stock was up 8.5% in after-hours trading Monday, after its earnings release, and is up 34% this year through Monday's regular session.The company makes human resources and financial software-as-a-service that users access via the Internet cloud, competing against longtime business software leaders Oracle (ORCL) and SAP (SAP).Workday is becoming a leading provider in human capital management and finance management software, analysts say. It's also rolling out data analytics software.Workday is leveraging the cloud, one of the fastest-growing areas of technology, to challenge Oracle and SAP, says Steve Koenig, an analyst for Wedbush Securities. The incumbents also are moving more to cloud offerings, but they've lagged, Koenig says."Workday is very small but they've got the entire Oracle and SAP base to feast on, and they are going to pick off a very significant piece of that base over time — there is no doubt about it," he said.Workday was co-founded by David Duffield, who is co-CEO. Duffield also founded PeopleSoft, another maker of HR software, which Oracle acquired in a hostile takeover in 2004.For the quarter ended Oct. 31, Workday reported a per-share loss, minus items, of 12 cents vs. a 39-cent loss in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected a per-share loss of 17 cents.Revenue rose 76% to $127.9 million, where analysts had expected $117.6 million.The company also announced that it had added Yahoo (YHOO) co-founder Jerry Yang to its board.For the current quarter, Workday expects revenue of $133 million to $138 million, up 63% to 69%. Analysts had expected $128.9 million, or growth of 58%.Workday doesn't provide an earnings outlook. Analysts expect a per-share loss ex items of 18 cents vs. a 19-cent loss in the year-ago period.The company is growing its core HR business while attracting more users to its financial platform, Workday co-CEO Aneel Bhusri told analysts on a conference call."We are translating our success in HR and moving it to financials," Bhusri said.Workday said it added 50 customers in Q3, including eight companies among the largest 2,000.Workday has emerged as the leading player among software-as-a-service companies that sell their products through a monthly or annual subscription via the cloud, says Scott Berg, an analyst for Northland Capital Markets."It's the fastest-growing company in all of SaaS right now," he said.But growth comes at a cost.Workday's research and development costs rose 76% in Q3. Its sales and marketing expenses rose 66%.Recruiting more salespeople and systems integrators is necessary for Workday to continue to challenge Oracle and SAP, Koenig says."They need to train and develop their sales force and third-party systems integrators," he said. "Their market footprint is a lot smaller than their competitors."Integrating its products is one key. The company is working on tightly integrating its human capital management software with its financial management product.That will be critical to attract larger customers, Berg says."Until Workday is able to sell that properly, I don't think some customers (can) switch all their HR over to Workday," he said.

The stock market today appeared poised for a mildly lower start despite upbeat Chinese factory data and a round of deal news.
Nasdaq 100 futures fell 2 points vs. fair value, while S&P 500 futures edged down less than 1 point. Dow futures lost 12 points.

Stocks had rallied last week, with the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 rising more than 1% each. The latter even hit a record high. A number of stocks including Celgene (CELG), Bit Auto (BITA), KapStone Paper (KS) and Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP) staged breakouts last week.
A preliminary reading of the HSBC/Markit PMI rose to 50.8 in June from 49.4 in May. Readings above 50 signal expansion. June marked the first above 50 read in six months and topped views for 49.7.

Delivering meaningful growth for a large, big-cap firm is no easy feat. Microsoft (MSFT) had some lackluster quarterly sales figures in parts of the past two fiscal years, but top-line growth has firmed.The Redmond, Wash.-based company has now put in three straight quarters of double-digit revenue gains. In the seven quarters prior to that, Microsoft's sales grew from 3% to 8%. In one of those periods, revenue declined 8%.Although Microsoft is best known as a software firm, some of its growth is expected to come from the hardware side. During its fiscal Q1 2014 conference call, the firm said hardware sales are slated to jump 35% to 45% in fiscal Q2, boosted by its recently expanded line of Surface tablets and the next-generation Xbox One video game console, which will be released Friday.Rival Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 just went on sale last week.Microsoft's earnings were flat last year and are expected to dip in fiscal 2014 ending in June . But profit is slated to grow 9% in fiscal 2015. Microsoft has a five-year Earnings Stability Factor of 8, signaling a steady stream of annual profits. The gauge runs from 0 (calm) to 99 (wild).The stock fell Monday after being downgraded to underperform from neutral at Bank of America/Merrill Lynch. Shares remain in a buy zone from a breakout past a 36.39 buy point from a handle. Microsoft rallied 43% this year before easing recently.Microsoft currently pays a quarterly dividend of 28 cents a share or $1.12 annually. It has a yield of about 3%, which is larger that that of the S&P 500's by about half of a percentage point. Its yield is a little less than that of networking giant Cisco Systems' (CSCO) 3.2%, but more than double that of database software titan Oracle (ORCL).In September, Microsoft hiked its dividend by a nickel a share to the current 28 cents a share. The dividend will be paid Dec. 12 to shareholders of record Nov. 21.

Oracle (ORCL) might be on the comeback trail.

The enterprise software giant is expected to at least meet Wall Street expectations, following two quarters of lackluster results. It reports results for its fiscal Q1 ended on or near Aug. 31 after the market close Wednesday.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Oracle to report earnings per share minus items of 56 cents, 3 cents better than the year-earlier quarter.

Revenue is expected to rise 3.2% to $8.47 billion, which would mark its biggest percentage jump in nearly two years. The company's year-over-year revenue the prior two quarters fell 1% and was flat, respectively.
An in-line quarter is most likely, said Matthew Hedberg, an analyst for RBC Capital Markets, in a research report on Monday.

"Looking for a rebound after a disappointing Q4 2013 and second-half 2013 characterized by execution/macro/FX head winds, we're anticipating an in-line start to the year, driven primarily by database and a stabilizing hardware business," he wrote.
Oracle executives have said the company could see some growth in its hardware business in fiscal Q1.
But Hedberg says it's too soon.
So does Steve Koenig, an analyst for Wedbush Securities.
"My estimate is that you would see growth in a hardware product line by Q2," he said.
For the current quarter, analysts expect EPS ex items of 69 cents, up 5 cents from the year-earlier period.
Revenue again is expected to rise 3.2%, to $9.4 billion.
Investors shouldn't expect a big beat on guidance, says Hedberg.
"With an improving macro environment, we anticipate Oracle to remain conservative in guidance," he wrote.

Salesforce.com's (CRM) northward growth trajectory is expected to continue as the company replaces aging customer relationship management systems with its cloud-based software and attracts more customers to its burgeoning marketing services business.

Salesforce.com is the No. 1 provider of customer relationship management software, delivering its software as a service via the Internet "cloud." It's set to report its earnings for its fiscal Q3 ended Oct. 31 after the close Monday, with its stock trading near all-time highs.
Salesforce.com's cloud-based service is an alternative to often more expensive on-premise systems sold by Oracle (ORCL), SAP (SAP) and other rivals.

The company earlier targeted its cloud service to small and midsize corporate customers, but it's been signing up larger customers, such as Coca-Cola (KO). The transition to larger customers could gain steam in the second half of this year, says Brad Sills, an analyst for Maxim Group.
"That is when large enterprises typically sign agreements ... so the expectation is that those large enterprise replacement deals start to close in Q3, Q4," Sills told IBD.

In July, Salesforce closed its $2.5 billion acquisition of ExactTarget, a marketing services company that Salesforce has combined with earlier acquisitions of Buddy Media, a social media marketing services company, and Radian6, a social media monitoring firm. Its goal is to create a one-stop shop for marketing and social media business applications.
ExactTarget will likely provide significant upside to Q3 revenue, Sills says.
"You only had three weeks of ExactTarget's revenue in last quarter's numbers and now you have a full quarter, which in my model is $55 million in total revenue," he said.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Salesforce to report total revenue of $1.05 billion, up 34% from the year-earlier period. They expect earnings per share minus items of 9 cents, up a penny.

For the current quarter, analysts expect revenue of $1.12 billion, up 34%, with EPS ex-items of 7 cents, down from 13 cents. The decline stems from restructuring charges associated with integrating ExactTarget.

Salesforce.com stock was flat in midday trading in the stock marketFriday, near 57. Earlier in the session, the stock touched an all-time high of 57.89, the third time in the past four days the stock has touched a new high. "In our view, SAP is beginning to deliver on its strategy to become a cloud vendor and connect its legacy on-premise apps to new app development in the cloud," Lenschow said…
Stocks notched uneven early gains Tuesday as investors weighed solid new home sales and mixed durable goods data against the potential for a deal between Greece and its eurozone creditors.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. The Nasdaq added less than 0.1%. The S&P 500 split the difference, up 0.2%.
Volume was mixed on the stock market today, up 5% on the Nasdaq and 8% lower on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Monday.

The top-line number in the Commerce Department's May durable goods report showed a 1.8% decline and a downward revision to April's number to minus 1.5%. Economists had forecast a more mild 0.6% slip. The bulk of the miss was apparently due to a sharp decline in aircraft orders during the month. Minus transportation, durable goods orders rose 0.5% — in line with expectations. So far this year, durable goods orders are running 2.2% below last year's January to May period.

Housing prices improved steadily in May, lifting the Federal Housing Finance Agency's House Price Index 0.3%. That increase was equal to March's increase but just below consensus forecasts for a 0.4% gain. Year over year, the index is up 5.3%.

New home sales popped in May to an annualized rate of 546,000, according to the Commerce Department. That was up from April's (upwardly revised) 534,000 pace, well above consensus expectations of 525,000 and the strongest number since Feb. 2008.

A bit less rosy was the preliminary June manufacturing estimate from researcher Markit. Its Purchasing Managers Manufacturing Index was at 53.4, down from May's 53.8 number and below forecasts for an increase to 54.2. The number points to a third month of slowing activity and is the gauge's weakest gain in 18 months.
In stocks, it was a good morning for Florida-based companies.

Darden Restaurants (DRI) rose 3% to lead the S&P 500 by a wide margin. The Orlando-based owner of the Olive Garden, Red Lobster and other chains reported healthy fiscal fourth-quarter results and announced plans to slice off a portion of its real estate assets into a separate real estate investment trust. The stock popped to a new high, paring some gains but holding just above a cup-base buy point of 70.48.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) pecked out a 2% gain, the best increase among Nasdaq 100 stocks. The Fort Lauderdale-headquartered software developer is still in buying range, 4% above a 69.33 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.
Among leaders, most of the IBD 50 list posted modest gains and losses — with a couple of dramatic exceptions.

Ambarella (AMBA) led the list with a 9% rebound. The stock tumbled 21% Monday, following a short-seller's report on Friday that questioned the stock's valuation. The stock remains extended after a mid-May rebound from 10-week support and is well above its 10-week moving average.

At the bottom of the group, burger joint Sonic (SONC) dived 11% in massive trade. Fiscal third quarter sales and profits met consensus expectations, but full-year earnings guidance didn't. UPDATE: Oracle late Tuesday released fiscal Q3 results that beat analyst views, rebounding from the previous quarter's disappointment. The database leader said per-share profit minus items rose 15% to 62 cents, while sales rose 3% to $9.04 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 56 cents and $9 billion. Oracle shares were up 3% after hours, just after the release.

The company's fiscal Q2 results, released in late December, lagged views, a rare miss for the business software giant. At that time, company co-President Safra Catz said "we do expect a significantly better quarter in Q3."
(Posted 3-19 2:25 p.m. ET)
The jury might still be out on Oracle.

One quarter after a rare instance in which the database leader reported a rare miss with its financial results, analysts are uncertain what to expect when the company reports fiscal Q3 results after the market close on Tuesday.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, on average, expect Oracle (ORCL) to post a profit minus items of 56 cents a share, up from 54 cents in both the year-ago quarter and the prior quarter.

Revenue is expected to inch up less than 3% to $9 billion from $8.8 billion in the year-ago period. That would roughly tie the previous quarter for the worst year-over-year comparison since the August 2009 quarter.
Oracle's Q2 miss was likely a glitch that won't have an overhang into Q3, says Richard Davis, an analyst for Canaccord Genuity, who has a hold rating on the stock.

"They might have a snapback quarter," Davis told IBD. "I don't know for sure, but in the last quarter they probably had some deals flip because companies said 'let's do a double check.' It doesn't mean the company isn't going to get those deals; they just got postponed."
Oracle's Q2 came at a time when other software companies also were dealing with customers still struggling through a tough economy, says Brent Thill, an analyst for UBS, who rates the stock a buy.

"Most of the software companies we spoke with had awful Novembers, the market was not feeling very healthy, and they had a bunch of deals that slipped," Thill said in an interview. "The playbook says don't bet against Oracle two quarters in a row on the negative side because historically, they have really bounced back. The thing I have learned following Oracle for over 10 years is that this company, when they are down, they get up fairly quick."
Others are less optimistic.

Average deal sizes might be too small to expect much upside beyond expectations in Q3, says Trip Chowdhry, an analyst for Global Equities Research. Chowdhry, though, rates Oracle's shares as overweight.

"What we are seeing is the scope of the projects are not getting larger, which tells us the deal sizes are not going to be big," he said in an interview. "And that is the reason we are saying Oracle would be able to meet the lower end of the guidance, but beating the top end of the guidance would be difficult.

"If they are going to beat the top end of the guidance, then we need to see some large deals that would give the (fiscal) fourth quarter a surprise, and our research has not indicated that."UPDATE: Oracle late Tuesday released fiscal Q3 results that beat analyst views, rebounding from the previous quarter's disappointment. The database leader said per-share profit minus items rose 15% to 62 cents, while sales rose 3% to $9.04 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 56 cents and $9 billion. Oracle shares were up 3% after hours, just after the release.The company's fiscal Q2 results, released in late December, lagged views, a rare miss for the business software giant. At that time, company co-President Safra Catz said "we do expect a significantly better quarter in Q3."***(Posted 3-19 2:25 p.m. ET)The jury might still be out on Oracle.One quarter after a rare instance in which the database leader reported a rare miss with its financial results, analysts are uncertain what to expect when the company reports fiscal Q3 results after the market close on Tuesday.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, on average, expect Oracle (ORCL) to post a profit minus items of 56 cents a share, up from 54 cents in both the year-ago quarter and the prior quarter.Revenue is expected to inch up less than 3% to $9 billion from $8.8 billion in the year-ago period. That would roughly tie the previous quarter for the worst year-over-year comparison since the August 2009 quarter.Oracle's Q2 miss was likely a glitch that won't have an overhang into Q3, says Richard Davis, an analyst for Canaccord Genuity, who has a hold rating on the stock."They might have a snapback quarter," Davis told IBD. "I don't know for sure, but in the last quarter they probably had some deals flip because companies said 'let's do a double check.' It doesn't mean the company isn't going to get those deals; they just got postponed."Oracle's Q2 came at a time when other software companies also were dealing with customers still struggling through a tough economy, says Brent Thill, an analyst for UBS, who rates the stock a buy."Most of the software companies we spoke with had awful Novembers, the market was not feeling very healthy, and they had a bunch of deals that slipped," Thill said in an interview. "The playbook says don't bet against Oracle two quarters in a row on the negative side because historically, they have really bounced back. The thing I have learned following Oracle for over 10 years is that this company, when they are down, they get up fairly quick."Others are less optimistic.Average deal sizes might be too small to expect much upside beyond expectations in Q3, says Trip Chowdhry, an analyst for Global Equities Research. Chowdhry, though, rates Oracle's shares as overweight."What we are seeing is the scope of the projects are not getting larger, which tells us the deal sizes are not going to be big," he said in an interview. "And that is the reason we are saying Oracle would be able to meet the lower end of the guidance, but beating the top end of the guidance would be difficult."If they are going to beat the top end of the guidance, then we need to see some large deals that would give the (fiscal) fourth quarter a surprise, and our research has not indicated that."
Salesforce.com continues to grow its cloud, but soon will go without its longtime chief financial officer.

The enterprise software company late Thursday reported fiscal Q4 earnings that beat analyst estimates, as the company leads Oracle (ORCL) and SAP (SAP) in customer relationship management software. Salesforce (CRM) is a pioneer in software delivered as a service via the Internet "cloud."
The company's revenue outlook for the current quarter also trumped expectations, but its EPS guidance was slightly short.
Salesforce.com also said that Graham Smith, its CFO since 2008, will retire in March 2015, and that its search for a new CFO has begun.

Salesforce stock was down a fraction in after-hours trading, after it released its earnings. The stock rose 3.9% in the regular session, touching a new high for the seventh day in the past 10 trading days.

The San Francisco-based company has steadily expanded its focus from mostly small businesses to the largest enterprises. It's also ramping up its marketing services business, aiming to be a one-stop shop that provides email, social media and other online marketing services to companies. It acquired email marketing services firm ExactTarget last year for $2.5 billion.

The 37% year-over-year sales growth for its quarter ended Jan. 31 follows growth of 28%, 31% and 36.5% in its previous quarters. That growth is a testament to Salesforce's CRM leadership, says Steven Ashley, analyst for Robert W. Baird & Co.
"Salesforce continues, even at their current level of penetration, to grow that business strongly," Ashley told IBD.

And selling more marketing services opens the door to new customers, says Alex Zukin, an analyst for Stephens. "The marketing cloud will be able to serve companies that market to consumers rather than to other businesses. That represents a big increase in the company's (total market)," he said.
For Q4, Salesforce reported earnings per share, minus items, of 7 cents, down 46% from the year-earlier period but a penny above the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Revenue hit $1.15 billion, where analysts had expected $1.13 billion.
For the current quarter, the firm had EPS ex items of 9-10 cents, vs. 10 cents in the year-ago period. Analysts were expecting 10 cents.
Salesforce expects Q1 revenue of $1.205 billion to $1.21 billion, up 35% to 36%, where analysts had modeled $1.187 billion.
ExactTarget Accelerates

ExactTarget accounted for more than $95 million in Q4 revenue and $194 million for the year, Smith said in the company's earnings conference call with analysts. And he said core CRM growth was robust.
" ... everyone can see by our numbers we had a spectacular finish to another year of just exceptional growth," Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff said on the call.
Benioff said Salesforce closed more than 200 seven-figure sales in the quarter, with more than 10 transactions of at least $10 million.
"That is really exceptional for a software company in the CRM space," Benioff said. "I know none of our peers are seeing these large transaction volumes like this."
Salesforce's cloud-based subscription software is becoming the preferred alternative to license-based models that require a large upfront fee and costly hardware support, Ashley says.

"When you buy software, you have to buy servers, databases, storage, and you have to have people (to manage it)," he said. "But when you buy it as a service, where it is provided to you like electricity, you don't have any of that on site. It goes back to the fundamental value proposition that the cloud is cheaper."

Oracle is ramping up the competition. On Monday, it said it would buy BlueKai, a cloud-based maker of data management and analytics software for Web advertising. In December, Oracle said it would buy Responsys, an email marketing services firm, for about $1.5 billion.

"I wouldn't be surprised if Salesforce copies" Oracle and buys a Blue Kai competitor, Steve Koenig, analyst for Wedbush Securities, told IBD.Salesforce.com continues to grow its cloud, but soon will go without its longtime chief financial officer.The enterprise software company late Thursday reported fiscal Q4 earnings that beat analyst estimates, as the company leads Oracle (ORCL) and SAP (SAP) in customer relationship management software. Red Hat continues to make gains in the cloud. The enterprise software company late Thursday posted Q4 earnings and revenue that topped Wall Street expectations. It's the fourth straight quarter EPS beat views. But the company issued a light outlook for the current quarter, and Red Hat (RHT) stock was down a fraction in after-hours trading. Red Hat stock rose…

Cornerstone OnDemand (CSOD) continues to invest heavily in business operations, as its Q4 bottom line missed analyst expectations and it forecast a deeper 2014 loss than Wall Street expected.Still, in early trading Wednesday, Cornerstone OnDemand stock was up as much as 3.5%, touching its all-time high of 60.43. But Cornerstone stock was down 2%, near 57, in afternoon trading in the stock market today.The Santa Monica, Calif.-based company late Tuesday reported Q4 revenue of $54.9 million, slightly below the consensus estimate but up 51% from the year-earlier quarter. The provider of software that customers access via the Internet "cloud" for various HR tasks has posted double-digit year-over-year revenue growth for at least the past 18 quarters.But the company reported a per-share loss minus items of 3 cents. Analysts expected break-even.Cornerstone guided Q1 sales at $56.5 million to $57.5 million, up 51% at the midpoint and in line with Wall Street estimates. Management also guided 2014 revenue above consensus estimates but forecast a loss of 24 cents for the year. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had forecast a 12-cent loss. Cornerstone has been investing heavily in a bid to boost market share.Several analysts remained upbeat.Credit Suisse maintained an outperform rating on Cornerstone and raised its price target to 63 from 57. Nomura maintained a buy rating and raised its price target to 62 from 56, citing strong billings."Cornerstone OnDemand continues to outgrow its competitors," wrote Nomura analyst Rick Sherlund in a research note.Cornerstone's software-as-a-service helps companies hire, train and manage employees."Cornerstone is the last remaining major independent talent manager," Sherlund wrote.Two years ago SAP (SAP) acquired talent management firm SuccessFactors for $3.4 billion. Oracle (ORCL) acquired Taleo, another competitor to Cornerstone, for $1.9 billion. Employee changeover at both the acquired companies has helped Cornerstone, Sherlund wrote.UBS analyst Brent Thill kept a neutral rating on Cornerstone but raised his price target to 60 from 51."Competition from Oracle and SAP remains benign as Cornerstone is winning more than its share, even among the largest enterprises," Thill wrote.The company says it has more than 1,600 clients worldwide, and nearly 14 million users. That's up from 1,400 clients and 12 million users as of June 30, 2012.Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter @IBD_BDeagon.

Veeva Systems delivered in its earnings-report debut. The maker of software for biotech and other life sciences companies late Thursday posted fiscal Q3 earnings and revenue that beat analyst views. It was its first quarterly report since its October IPO. Its outlook for the current quarter also exceeded estimates. Veeva (VEEV) stock was up 4.5% in after-hours trading, after it…

Some of tech's biggest giants might ultimately claim the largest share of the emerging multibillion-dollar Big Data market, though they are playing catch-up.Oracle (ORCL), SAP (SAP) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) are scrambling to tackle Big Data and compete with nimble newcomers such as Splunk (SPLK) and Tableau Software (DATA).Big Data in general describes the large volume of data companies are accumulating from multiple sources in the digital age, and how to best manage and use that data with analytics software and services. (See related story, this page.)Tableau and Splunk are notching 50% to 70% quarterly year-over-year sales growth rates for their analytics software, which helps companies analyze their Big Data. But analysts say Oracle, SAP, HP and other big vendors will move deeper into the field, boosted by acquisitions.It will happen, but not overnight, says Dan Vesset, an analyst for market tracker IDC."The (software vendors) realize this is real, this is the future," Vesset said. "If you are not providing a solution that deals with large amounts of data, then you are going to be left out of a large segment of the market."By 2014, we will see an acceleration of M&As, but it will probably take five years-plus (before large companies dominate Big Data)."Research firm MarketsandMarkets agrees, saying smaller firms offering analytics and business intelligence software will dominate in the near term before larger tech companies catch up."Considering the complex ecosystem of the Big Data market, pure-play vendors such as Tableau, Karmasphere, Cloudera, Splunk, etc. are expected to reap the most benefit," the research firm told IBD via email. "However, as Big Data solutions get commoditized, the demand for integrated Big Data solutions will increase and leading hardware and software vendors such as IBM (IBM), HP, Dell, Oracle, SAP and EMC (EMC) will gain substantial market share in the coming years."The big boys already are jumping in. For example, in September SAP said it would acquire Kxen, a Big Data software analytics company. Terms weren't disclosed.Still, some of the young guns might survive long enough to challenge IBM and Oracle, says Aapo Markkanen, an analyst for ABI Research."It's quite likely the new generation of Big Data firms like Splunk are going to make it," he said. "Some of them will live up to the challenge, but not all of them."Venture capital will aid the startups.Enterprise software firms have attracted $893 million in venture funding this year through August. That compares with $877 million for all of 2012 and $726 million in 2011, says IDC.But even a robust Big Data market can't support everyone, says IDC's Vesset."These new guys are doing a lot of innovative and interesting things, but it's no different than any other market, whether it's soft drinks or cars," he said. "Some of (the startups) may make it, but the vast majority will either be incorporated into bigger companies, remain small or go out of business."Software to help with Big Data is needed because Big Data is getting ... bigger. Companies are becoming overwhelmed with the growing amount of data from data centers, websites, mobile phones, social media and other sources.Edmunds.com uses analytics software produced by Splunk to examine traffic trends, security concerns and other issues across four auto-related websites that it operates. Dell has used analytics software from privately held Ayata to improve its relations with customers by finding a better way to sift through data from thousands of customer service agents spread across multiple locations. The NBA's Portland Trail Blazers used data analytics software from privately held Ayasdi to better analyze statistics in order to improve its player drafts.Companies want solutions. And vendors want to cash in. And nobody on either side of that equation wants to be left out, says Douglas Laney, an analyst for research firm Gartner."Vendors see it as a Gold Rush to be a provider of Big Data-related technology capabilities and services," he said. "And companies are looking to take advantage of all of this data that is available."In an August report, MarketsandMarkets said it expects global Big Data revenue to reach $46.34 billion in 2018 vs. $14.87 billion this year. This month, Gartner forecast Big Data spending near $55 billion in 2016, up from $33 billion this year. Last January, IDC said it expects Big Data to produce revenue of $23.8 billion in 2016.ABI Research says global revenue from Big Data could reach $114 billion in 2018, up from $31 billion this year.ABI says salaries account for 50% of the spending as Big Data vendors and their enterprise customers alike hire data scientists and other experts to find the best ways to leverage data.Professional services remain the top priority for Big Data spending for now, says Gartner's Laney."We see almost a five-to-one demand for services compared to technology right now," he said. "One-third of the organizations can't hire the type of talent they are looking for."But spending on hardware and software systems will become more prevalent, Laney says."Like with any new type of technology or concept it becomes very services-heavy at the beginning," he said. "We are still in the early days ... Over time software is gaining ground."

Cisco Systems (CSCO) CEO John Chambers on Tuesday predicted "brutal" consolidation within the IT industry, as the company unveiled a new software pricing model and analysts mulled the fallout from the National Security Agency's alleged eavesdropping on its computer networking business. "You are going to see a brutal, brutal consolidation of the IT industry where out of the top five…

Ruling the cloud services business is one road to glory for new Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella, but Amazon.com's leading Amazon Web Services stands in the way.AWS is by far the biggest provider of infrastructure-as-a-service, in which companies rent computers and data storage via the Internet cloud.In cloud services, Microsoft (MSFT) first targeted platform-as-a-services — applications, databases and software that run on cloud infrastructure — but it's been gaining traction as an IaaS provider.Emerging as a strong No. 2 to Amazon.com (AMZN) might be enough to win kudos from growth-hungry Microsoft shareholders, analysts say.Neither Amazon nor Microsoft breaks out cloud revenue in their financial results. Analysts have estimated 2013 revenue for AWS at $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion, which they say represents a 50% to 70% jump from 2012.Microsoft's cloud revenue also is hard to nail down. BMO Capital Markets estimates it's a more than $1 billion business, but that includes license revenue from software Microsoft has retooled to operate on its Azure cloud platform.Nadella, who was executive vice president of Microsoft's cloud and enterprise group before being named last month to replace Steve Ballmer as CEO, played a lead role in moving Microsoft to the cloud, along with Ray Ozzie, Microsoft's former chief software architect, who left the company in 2010.Some analysts expect the Amazon-Microsoft rivalry to heat up as Nadella targets cloud computing growth."Microsoft may need a strong No. 1 to chase, and they have that in Amazon," said James Staten, an analyst at Forrester Research. "In the video console market, they had (Sony's (SNE) PlayStation, which helped them rise with Xbox.'Cloud-First World'"AWS views only Microsoft and potentially Google (GOOG) as their main (cloud) competitors. They're not really concerned about anyone else."Nadella hasn't said much about any cloud rivalry since being named CEO. But in a letter to Microsoft employees, he wrote: "Our job is to ensure Microsoft will thrive in a mobile and cloud-first world."AWS and Microsoft face rivals besides Google in cloud computing services, such as IBM (IBM), Oracle (ORCL), VMware (VMW) and Salesforce.com (CRM). IBM last year acquired IaaS vendor SoftLayer for about $2 billion. It also recently purchased Cloudant and plans to invest $1 billion in PaaS.2.5 Million ServersAWS and Microsoft, though, have strengths most rivals have trouble matching, analysts say.Amazon expanded into cloud computing as a way to efficiently utilize the massive e-commerce infrastructure it had built up for its own needs. According to one estimate, Amazon has mustered nearly 2.5 million computer servers to power its public cloud services.Microsoft, its PC and server software widely deployed in corporations, built its own in-house cloud infrastructure to support Office 365, Xbox Live, Bing and other products.Still, AWS is much bigger. And Oracle has moved faster than Microsoft in making cloud-related acquisitions, says Nomura analyst Rick Sherlund in a research report."New management must drive much harder to the cloud," said Sherlund. "It is not too late for either Microsoft or Oracle for PaaS. It is too late for them for leadership in IaaS; they can never catch AWS at the scale they operate."Microsoft, like VMware, has been adapting as corporate data centers move to cloud technology, says Citigroup analyst Walter Pritchard. VMware's virtualization software is widely used in corporate data centers to increase the flexibility and capabilities of computer servers.VMware and its majority owner, EMC (EMC), last year launched Pivotal Software, a cloud computing venture that is developing PaaS products that work on Amazon's public cloud platform.Windows-Only FocusMicrosoft's strategic focus is still on Windows Server and other legacy products, says Pritchard."With a Windows-only focus, it will be difficult for Microsoft to complete broadly in IaaS. Instead, it must be successful reinvigorating developers around the Azure platform with (PaaS) offerings," wrote Pritchard in a research note.Forrester's Staten agrees it's vital for Microsoft to attract more software developers to create cloud apps.The early success of AWS was in making it easy for small and midsize businesses to tap computing resources via the Internet cloud that had only been available to large enterprises. AWS has more recently targeted large companies and other enterprises.Microsoft's "walled-garden" approach still aims at locking in customers to its software ecosystem, some analysts say.David Smith, an analyst at research firm Gartner, says Microsoft's Azure cloud platform still needs to invest more in the IaaS market, which is much bigger than the PaaS market.Customers pay IaaS service providers pennies an hour per server. Amazon has cut its cloud prices nearly 40 times since 2006. Since moving into IaaS last year, Microsoft has been cutting prices to match Amazon."Microsoft has a long history of doing things its own way," Smith told IBD. "But in IaaS, they're starting to focus on not just Microsoft OS, (by also focusing on) Linux and Java. I expect to see more of that kind of thinking in the cloud."

Tableau Software continued to find gold helping companies sift through a deluge of data, reporting blowout fourth-quarter earnings late Tuesday that sent shares soaring to all-time highs. The data analytics firm earned 20 cents a share ex items vs. 4 cents a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected a break-even Q4. Revenue jumped 95% to $81.5 million, the…

The rapid growth story for Tableau Software (DATA) is expected to continue when the enterprise software company reports its fourth quarter results after the market close on Tuesday. Tableau competes with much larger rivals including Oracle (ORCL) and SAP (SAP) in selling data analytics software to help companies better manage growing reams of data coming from multiple sources including PCs,…

Tibco Software posted Q4 earnings above views late Thursday, but license revenue disappointed and its outlook for the current quarter fell well short of expectations. Tibco (TIBX) stock was down 14% in after-hours trading, after it released its results. For its fiscal Q1 ending Feb. 28, Tibco expects earnings per share minus items of 17-18 cents on revenue of $247…
Tableau Software  (DATA) may be rewriting the definition of a fast-growth technology company.

The data analytics software company offered its best case to date for the title earlier this month when it blew away analysts views for its fourth quarter highlighted by year-over-year quarterly revenue growth of 95%. Analysts had expected 60% growth.
Investors responded in kind, sending shares soaring by over 12% on Feb. 5, a day after its Q4 results.
The stock is up 45% this year after ending 2013 up 122% from its IPO offering price of 31 on May 17.

Tableau Software is one member of an emerging club of young gun software players catching on with investors as they challenge multibillion technology stalwarts such as Oracle (ORCL), SAP (SAP) and IBM (IBM) with innovative methods for managing electronic data, says Derrick Wood, an analyst for Susquehanna Financial Group.

"That is the appetite these days, you look across the landscape, Workday (WDAY), Splunk (SPLK), Tableau, all of these stocks are just up and to the right, and it's such a dynamic time in technology and some of these vendors are very disruptive with big growth curves, and valuations are getting bid up on an appetite to own these names," he said.
Charting Territory
Tableau's software lets companies sift through data from multiple departments and arrange that information in charts and graphs.

The primary difference between Tableau and some of its rivals is that its software can be used by most office staff without the help of information technology departments, says Steven Ashley, an analyst for Robert W. Baird & Co.
"Tableau is coming into the market with tools that provide better visualizations of data that the common man or knowledge worker can use," he said.

In the quarter, Tableau reported a per-share profit, minus items, of 20 cents due to a one-time tax benefit vs. 4 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected a break-even quarter. Revenue in the quarter jumped 95% to $81.5 million vs. the same quarter last year.

For the current period, the company said it expects revenue of $61 million to $63 million, or growth of 52.5% to 57.4% from the year-earlier quarter. Analysts had expected $60 million, or growth of 50%.
Many investors have a one-track mind when looking at Tableau, says Daniel Ives, an analyst for FBR Capital Markets.

"They are buying on the revenue growth; at the end of the day you can count on one hand the type of quality companies that are growing at this pace in these types of secular areas," he said. "Relative to expectations, they kind of blew the cover off the ball."
In the quarter, Tableau's license revenue grew 92.9% to $58 million vs. the year-earlier period. Revenue from maintenance and service shot up 99.6% to $23.4 million.
Tableau released a new version of its software in November and is planning another new version in Q2 and yet another next year.

During a conference call with analysts to discuss its earnings, CEO Christian Chabot said Tableau expanded relationships with several large existing customers, including Google (GOOG) and Ford Motor (F).
Expanding Use
Tableau's ability to find ways for customers to use its software is providing the fuel for much of its growth, Ives says.
"The new products help, but once Tableau gets in the door they are really able to expand their overall presence and that has been on their keys to success," he said.
Is it enough? Analysts expect Tableau's year-over-year revenue growth to begin to decelerate to 57% in Q1 and 45% in Q2 after a steady climb from 62% to 95% the past four quarters.
And Q1 is a particularly slow period for software companies.

Many of Tableau's deployments are in specific departments rather than across a company. Pushing beyond that boundary could compromise the business model that has made Tableau a favorite among knowledge workers and the reason for its success, Wood says.

"If they want to get into the market in signing bigger platformwide deals, they are going to need to tailor not just to the business user but to IT," he said. "When you start getting into bigger deployments, there is a need for security and schema and structure and compliance — all of that stuff that IT needs to be in control of."
Investing In The Business
In the quarter, Tableau's sales and marketing costs rose 72.9% to $40.1 million vs. the year-earlier period while R&D spending climbed 76.2% to $18.2 million vs. the same quarter last year.
Tableau's global message is gaining traction. Its international business represented 22% of revenue in Q4 vs. 18% in the prior quarter.
Growth does come at a price.

"The biggest challenge is managing rapid growth," Ashley said. "If you are growing your business at 70%, 80%, 90% (annually) you have to hire 70% or 80% or 90% more people, more office space (and) more computer capacity."

Tableau must keeping pushing the big boys such as Oracle and SAP, said Ives: "There is a big opportunity in the installed base that is the traditional analytics vendors and it's really going after that opportunity. That is really the golden nugget."Tableau Software  (DATA) may be rewriting the definition of a fast-growth technology company.The data analytics software company offered its best case to date for the title earlier this month when it blew away analysts views for its fourth quarter highlighted by year-over-year quarterly revenue growth of 95%.
